qas.question: Which of the wood in a growth ring is usually darker?
Which property of a tree's wood that gives clues about its strength and hardness can be judged by it's color?
What category of trees show this difference greatly?
What type of woods might sometimes appear to have darker earlywood on a finished surface?
With the exception of earlywood/latewood difference in some types of trees, how much of an indication of strength is a wood's color?

context: Since the <a0_0>latewood<a0_0/> of a growth ring is usually darker in color than the earlywood, this fact may be used in judging the <a1_0>density<a1_0/>, and therefore the hardness and strength of the material. This is particularly the case with <a2_0>coniferous<a2_0/> woods. In <a3_0>ring-porous<a3_0/> woods the vessels of the early wood not infrequently appear on a finished surface as darker than the denser latewood, though on cross sections of heartwood the reverse is commonly true. Except in the manner just stated the color of wood is <a4_0>no indication<a4_0/> of strength.
